goal.ch: Introducing the fundamental concepts and advanced topics of quantum mechanics.
goal.en: Introducing the fundamental concepts and advanced topics of quantum mechanics.

outline.ch:
Building on the foundation of quantum mechanics established in Quantum Mechanics I, this course introduces approximation methods for addressing real-world problems. Key topics include time-dependent perturbation theory, variational methods, adiabatic approximation and Berry‘s phase, scattering theory, systems of identical particles, second quantization, relativistic quantum mechanics, density matrices, and path integral formalism.
In addition to theoretical tools, the course emphasizes the physics of model systems and their broader implications for AMO physics, condensed matter physics, high energy physics, and quantum information science.
The course will cover most topics from Chapters 5–8 of Sakurai and Napolitano‘s textbook.
If time permits, it will also explore modern topics such as quantum speed limits, open quantum systems, quantum foundations, and elements of quantum computation and quantum information.
Prerequisite: Students who have already taken Quantum Mechanics I or are otherwise comfortable with manipulating Dirac‘s bra-ket notation.
--------------------------------------------
Useful graduate-level references:
1. R. Bertlmann and N. Friis - Modern Quantum Theory: From Quantum Mechanics to Entanglement and Quantum Information, Oxford University Press, 2023.
2. N. Zettili - Quantum Mechanics: Concepts and Applications, 3rd Edition, Wiley, 2022.
3. I. Bengtsson and K. Życzkowski - Geometry of Quantum States: An Introduction to Quantum Entanglement, 2nd Edition, Cambridge University Press, 2017.
4. S. Weinberg - Lectures on Quantum Mechanics, 2nd Edition, Cambridge University Press, 2015.
5. M. Nielsen and I. L. Chuang - Quantum Computation and Quantum Information, 10th Anniversary Edition, Cambridge University Press, 2010.
6. G. Auletta, M. Fortunato, and G. Parisi - Quantum Mechanics, Cambridge University Press, 2009.
7. K. Gottfried and T.-M. Yan - Quantum Mechanics: Fundamentals, 2nd Edition, Springer, 2003. [ebook ISBN: 9780387216232]
8. A. Messiah - Quantum Mechanics, Dover Publications, 1999.
9. A. Peres - Quantum Theory: Concepts and Methods, Springer, 1993.
10. R. Shankar - Principles of Quantum Mechanics, 2nd Edition, Springer, 1994.
11. L. D. Landau and E. M. Lifshitz - Quantum Mechanics: Non-Relativistic Theory, 3rd Edition, Butterworth-Heinemann, 1981.
Useful undergraduate-level references:
12. B. Zwiebach - Mastering Quantum Mechanics: Essentials, Theory, and Applications, MIT Press, 2022. [See also MIT OCW 8.04 to 8.06, Quantum Physics]
13. D. J. Griffiths and D. F. Schroeter - Introduction to Quantum Mechanics, 3rd Edition, Cambridge University Press, 2018.
14. B. Schumacher and M. Westmoreland - Quantum Processes, Systems, and Information, Cambridge University Press, 2010.
15. S. Gasiorowicz - Quantum Physics, 3rd Edition, Wiley, 2003.
16. R P. Feynman - The Feynman Lectures on Physics: Volume III, 1965. [https://www.feynmanlectures.caltech.edu/III_toc.html]
Usefule Online Resources:
17. R. G. Littlejohn (Berkeley) - Lecture notes on quantum mechanics, https://bohr.physics.berkeley.edu/classes/221/2021/221.html
18. D. Tong (Cambridge) - Lectures on Topics in Quantum Mechanics, http://www.damtp.cam.ac.uk/user/tong/topicsinqm.html
19. B. Simons (Cambridge) - Part II: Advanced Quantum Mechanics, http://www.tcm.phy.cam.ac.uk/~bds10/aqp.html
20. R. Fitzpatrick (Austin) - Quantum Mechanics, https://farside.ph.utexas.edu/teaching/qm/Quantum/index.html
21. M. Fowler (Virgina) - Graduate Quantum Mechanics Lectures, http://galileo.phys.virginia.edu/classes/751.mf1i.fall02/home.html
22. M. Lukin (Harvard) - Modern Atomic and Optical Physics II, https://lukin.physics.harvard.edu/teaching
